Threat Description: Attacker intercepts/replays OAuth codes/tokens to impersonate the user during Google login.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Enforce TLS 1.2+ end-to-end; HSTS enabled
Require PKCE for public clients
Validate state and nonce on callback
Use short-lived access tokens and rotating refresh tokens
NIST CSF Reference: PR.AA-01: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization.
ISO 27001: A.9.2.4 Management of secret authentication information of users
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 8: Identify users and authenticate access to system components
SOC 2: CC6.2 Logical access security measures are implemented to protect assets
OWASP: ASVS V2.1 Authentication design; OWASP API Security: API2 Broken Authentication

Threat Description: Client manipulates request parameters/IDs to bypass authorization (BOLA/BFLA).
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Enforce server-side object ownership checks on every resource ID
Deny by default, allow by policy (RBAC/ABAC)
Validate JWT scope/claims on each request
Reject unexpected/extra fields via strict schema validation
NIST CSF Reference: PR.AA-04: Access to data, assets, and devices is limited to authorized users, processes, and devices.
ISO 27001: A.9.1.2 Access to networks and services controlled
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 7: Restrict access to cardholder data by business need to know
SOC 2: CC6.4 Logical access is restricted to authorized personnel
OWASP: OWASP API Security: API1 Broken Object Level Authorization
GDPR: Art. 25 Data protection by design and by default

Threat Description: Injection via unsafe queries grants admin-level operations.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Use parameterized queries/ORM bind parameters only
Disable raw queries or review/approve tightly
DB accounts least-privilege with separated roles
Automated SAST/DAST for injection patterns
NIST CSF Reference: PR.DS-06: Mechanisms for data integrity are implemented and tested.
ISO 27001: A.12.6.1 Technical vulnerability management; A.9.2.3 Management of privileged access rights
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 6.2/6.3: Secure software and applications; Req. 6.5: Address common coding vulnerabilities
SOC 2: CC6.6 Controls protect against injection and other attacks

Threat Description: ID/Access tokens stored in localStorage/sessionStorage leaked via XSS or logs.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Use HttpOnly, Secure, SameSite cookies for tokens (no web-storage)
Do not log tokens; redact secrets
Rotate tokens and implement revocation
NIST CSF Reference: PR.DS-05: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating least privilege and separation of duties.
ISO 27001: A.10.1.1 Cryptographic controls; A.9.4.1 Information access restriction
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 3.4: Protect stored account data; Req. 8.3: Strong authentication
SOC 2: CC6.1 Policies and procedures constrain logical access
OWASP: ASVS V3.4 Sensitive data storage; OWASP Cheat Sheet: Token Binding

Threat Description: Manipulated redirect_uri or rogue client_id causes token leakage to attacker domain.
Security Task Title: Strict OAuth Client & Redirect URI Policy
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Register exact redirect URIs (no wildcards)
Enforce HTTPS on redirect URIs
Validate iss/aud/azp claims against expected values
NIST CSF Reference: PR.AA-01: Identities and credentials are managed.
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 8.2: Strong cryptography and secure protocols for authentication

Threat Description: Attacker tampers with alg/claims or uses unsigned tokens; backend fails to verify.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Verify signature against trusted JWKS; pin issuer
Enforce alg allow-list (e.g., RS256)
Check exp/nbf/aud/iss; reject ‘none’ alg
ISO 27001: A.14.1.2 Securing application services on public networks
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 6.5.9: Verify authenticity of all sessions and tokens
SOC 2: CC7.2 Monitoring and detection for anomalies
OWASP: ASVS V3.2 Token integrity; OWASP JWT Cheat Sheet

Threat Description: Path traversal or direct URL access exposes sensitive files.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Serve files via authorized API only; no direct disk paths
Implement allow-list and anti-path-traversal checks
Enforce RBAC on file access
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 7.2: Protect public access to sensitive resources
OWASP: OWASP Top 10 A01:2021 Broken Access Control; A05:2021 Security Misconfiguration

Threat Description: Flooding requests or WebSocket messages exhausts resources causing outage.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Per-IP/user throttling with bursts and quotas
Global concurrency caps; circuit breakers
Upstream WAF/DDoS and timeout/backpressure
NIST CSF Reference: DE.CM-07: Monitoring for unusual activity and thresholds.
SOC 2: CC7.2 Security monitoring detects and reports events
OWASP: OWASP API Security: API4 Lack of Resources & Rate Limiting

Threat Description: Insufficient logs let attackers deny actions; investigations lack evidence.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Log auth events, token issuance/refresh/revocation, admin actions
Protect logs (WORM/append-only), time-sync, retention/alerting
Pseudonymize PII in logs
NIST CSF Reference: PR.PT-01: Audit log records are generated, protected, and reviewed.
ISO 27001: A.12.4.1 Event logging; A.12.4.3 Administrator and operator logs
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 10: Log and monitor all access to system components and data
SOC 2: CC7.3 The entity designs and implements procedures to log, monitor, and review security events
GDPR: Art. 30 Records of processing activities; Art. 32

Threat Description: Over-permissive CORS or origin trust leads to cross-origin token/data leakage.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Set exact allow-origin (no ‘*’ with credentials)
Disallow credentials unless required; limit methods/headers
Validate origin on sensitive endpoints
SOC 2: CC6.7 Controls restrict data transmission and sharing

Threat Description: If tokens are in cookies, CSRF can trigger state-changing requests.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: SameSite=Lax/Strict, Secure, HttpOnly
CSRF tokens with double-submit/origin checks
Re-authenticate for high-risk actions
ISO 27001: A.14.1.2 Protecting application services on public networks
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 6.5: Address common coding vulnerabilities (incl. CSRF)
SOC 2: CC6.8 System components are protected from alteration
OWASP: ASVS V3.5 Session management; OWASP CSRF Cheat Sheet

Assets: Secrets Management (API keys, DB creds, JWKS cache)
Threat Description: Hard-coded secrets or insecure env handling exposes credentials.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Store secrets in a vault (not repo/env files in images)
Rotate keys regularly; least-privilege for secrets access
Monitor for secret leakage (SCM scanning)
NIST CSF Reference: PR.DS-01: Data is managed consistent with risk strategy (incl. key management).
ISO 27001: A.10.1.1 Cryptographic controls; A.9.2.4 Secret authentication information
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 3.6: Protect cryptographic keys; Req. 2.2.5 Secure configurations
SOC 2: CC6.1 Logical access control policies and procedures

Threat Description: Session fixation or missing rotation after OAuth login enables hijacking.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Regenerate session identifiers after login and privilege changes
Bind session to device/IP heuristics where appropriate
Short idle/absolute timeouts
NIST CSF Reference: PR.AA-03: Authentication to assets is enforced with session management.

Threat Description: Large or numerous uploads/downloads saturate bandwidth and disk causing service degradation.
User Story Acceptance Criteria as Mitiga: Enforce file size/type limits and implement chunking/backpressure
Apply per-user/tenant quotas with graceful 429 responses
Use asynchronous processing and request timeouts
NIST CSF Reference: DE.CM-07: Monitoring thresholds and alerts; PR.PT-04: Resource controls are implemented.
ISO 27001: A.12.1.3 Capacity management; A.14.2.7 Outsourced development security
PCI DSS Reference: Req. 1.5: Monitor and control system components for performance and availability
OWASP: OWASP ASVS V12 Files and resources; OWASP Top 10 A10:2021 Server-Side Request Forgery (contextual rate limits)
